Award.AwardTitle: SI2-SSE Collaborative Research: Molecular Simulations of Polymer Nanostructures in the Cloud

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The use of polymers, their composites, and nanostructures is growing at a fast pace, both by displacing traditional materials and by enabling emerging technologies. Examples range from the all-composite airframe of the Boeing 787 and the new Airbus 350 to wearable electronics. This project aims to develop a software infrastructure to simulate these materials with atomic resolution and make these tools universally accessible and useful via on-line computing. These simulations have the potential to accelerate the development of optimized material formulations that can benefit society and reduce the associated costs by combining physical with computational experiments. Making these advanced tools available for free online simulations and complementing them with tutorials and educational material will encourage their use in the classroom and will impact the education of new generations of engineers and scientists familiar with these powerful tools that will be required to address tomorrow's challenges.

The objective of this effort is to enable pervasive, reproducible molecular simulations of polymeric materials using state-of-the-art tools and with quantified uncertainties building on recent breakthroughs in molecular simulations, cyber-infrastructure and uncertainty quantification. The framework will consist of three main components: i) powerful simulation tools for polymer nano structures including: state-of-the-art molecular builders, a parallel MD engine with stencils that enable efficient structure relaxation and property characterization and post-processing codes; ii) a UQ framework to orchestrate the molecular simulations and propagate uncertainties in input parameters to predictions and compare the predictions to experimental values; iii) databases of force fields and molecular structures as well as predicted and experimental properties. The simulation framework will be deployed via NSF's nanoHUB where users will be able to run online simulations without downloading or installing any software while expert users will have the option to download, modify and contribute to the infrastructure. Usage of and contributions to the software framework will be facilitated and encouraged via online and in-person user guides, learning modules and research tutorials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Predictive simulations of polymers and its composites are important for a wide range of applications, from structural composites for aerospace to polymer electrolytes for energy and electronics. These models and the associated tools, synergistically combined with experiments, could help accelerate the development of new materials or assess existing ones. The goal of this was to make molecular simulations of polymers pervasive, making these tools available not just to few computational groups, but to researchers, instructors and students, see Figure 1.

 

Intellectual merit. We leveraged cloud computing capabilities in NSF?s nanoHUB to deploy a series of tools for the simulation of polymers and its composites. Using nanoHUB, users can perform fully interactive simulations from their web-browsers, without downloading or installing any software. Access to these resources is free of charge and the hardware resources required to perform computationally intensive tasks are provided. During this effort, we enhanced the PolymerModeler (https://nanohub.org/tools/polymod) tool that creates highly accurate molecular structures of polymers starting from the specification of one or few monomers. We also created and deployed full scientific workflows using Jupyter. The glass transition temperature calculation notebook (https://nanohub.org/tools/tgnb) enables users to: i) select a monomer, ii) build  and relax a structure using PolymerModeler, iii) run molecular dynamics simulations using the LAMMPS code, and iv) postprocess the results to extract the desired quantity of interest. Users can modify each step of the process to fit their needs and explore the materials of their interest. In addition, we performed research on best practices and uncertainty quantification in polymer simulations, to be able to assess the accuracy of the predictions from our tools.

 

Broader impact. These tools are experiencing significant usage in nanoHUB. During this grant 1032 new users run simulations using PolymerModeler, including in classroom settings, see Figure 2. Importantly, the tool was used in 11 publications by authors unrelated to this projecs or its investigators. The glass transition notebook has been used by 85 unique users. This shows translation of our research into the classroom and to other researchers. In addition, during the summer of 2017, Mr. Carlos Patino an undergraduate student of physics, joined and contribute the implementation and development of the new tool Struct2LAMMPS as a Jupyter notebook. The tool this undergraduate student help build, the LAMMPS Data-File Generator, helps users setup a molecular dynamics simulation and has been used by 359 individuals. Thus, the project provided educational/development opportunities to an undergraduate student and a graduate student who led the development of best practices in polymer simulations and simulation tools.
